thread.title: 'Give us better transport links between east and west', demand North's major ports
thread.title_full: 'Give us better transport links between east and west', demand North's major ports

author: Jonathan Walker
title: 'Give us better transport links between east and west', demand North's major ports
text:
'Give us better transport links between east and west', demand North's major ports 18:30, 13 Sep 2016 By Jonathan Walker Four major ports in the North, including the Port of Tyne, have joined forces to create a new partnership to boost the economy Shares Get daily news by email Extended facilities at Riverside Quay, Port of Tyne 
The four major ports of the North of England called for investment of £100m to improve road and rail links as they joined forces to launch a new Northern Ports Association. 
Port of Tyne has joined forces with Tees Valley, Liverpool and Hull and Humber ports to create the new partnership, which officially got under way at a signing ceremony in the House of Commons attended by Transport Minister John Hayes and other senior politicians. 
The Northern Ports Association is designed to boost North’s imports and exports. 
And in one of its first acts, it launched a campaign for better road and rail links between the North East and North West. 
The association said investment of £100m could give the economy a major boost. Views from the Tyne Cruise, Port of Tyne 
It follows the launch of a report by think tank IPPR North in June, which highlighted the dominance of southern ports and the problems this creates in transporting imports and exports across the UK. 
At the moment, 60% of freight destined for the North is delivered to southern ports - leading to unnecessary motorway traffic, delays, pollution and inefficiency. 
But IPPR North and the new association says that the North can act as a genuine gateway to the world, connecting Atlantic shipping in Liverpool in the west to the east’s links with the Continent. Read More Huge cruise ship docks at Port of Tyne on busiest ever day bringing thousands to the region 
Andrew Moffat, Port of Tyne chief executive officer, said: “We will be working in partnership to establish a forum to see how we can work together to meet our aspirations for better connectivity in the northern region, to help us continue to improve services in the North East for the benefit of businesses and all other stakeholders of the Port of Tyne.” 
Ed Cox, director of IPPR North, said: “Post-Brexit, the Northern Powerhouse agenda is more important than ever. 
“Far from the powerhouse being a Whitehall-led scheme, northern businesses are taking control and creating much-needed jobs and prosperity. Ed Cox - Director, IPPR North. The Journal and Ward Hadaway's 2015 Fastest 50 Business Awards held at the Baltic, Gateshead. 
“For just £100m, the Government could open-up east-west port connections and create a genuine gateway to a global North. 
“This is exactly the kind of ‘shovel-ready’ project HM Treasury looks to be eyeing-up ahead of the Autumn Statement.” 
The Port of Tyne, which manages the Tyne port, is a statutory body governed by legislation and controlled by an independent board. It has no shareholders, and any profit is invested into the organisation and its work. 
It’s responsible for a 19-mile stretch of the River Tyne, and three miles of sea outside of the piers. 
The port’s turnover in 2015 was £58.8m. It handled five million tonnes of cargo in the same year.
